ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: good
At least 15 hours per week, the homeworks required time, but I gained a lot from them.
roughly 10 to 15 hours.
25-30 depending on when a homework assignment was due
sometimes there is too much homework
15-20 hours
6h
6hrs
10 hrs
5-7 hours per week
approximately 10 hours per week
Fifteen
8 hours
5-6 hours
I spent upwards of 10 hours per week on this course.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: good
Time consuming

I am learning a lot from this course but the homework assignments are extremely time consuming. I certainly learn the material through doing them, but this could be achieved with more targeted assignments.
This is a great course, I really appreciate all of the detail that is provided in the lecture notes, which I consider extremely straight forward in comparison to other biostats courses taught here.
This course is very useful and interesting.

This course was excellent. The lectures were clear, well organized, logical, and useful. The lecture slides from this class will be an excellent resource for me in the future. The text book selected for this class was also an excellent choice. I appreciated that the lectures and the text readings coincided.
Strengths: Material is goodWeaknesses: too much workload
It's a good course. I learned a lot.

The slides in this class are very good, but the lecture is way too long and hard to stay engaged in because everything is on the slides and they are basically just read to us. The homework is way too long and as such loses its value, you are not trying to learn the material but get through it as quickly as possible because the problem sets take between 20-25 hours to complete.
excellent

Nice thorough overview of survival analysis though some was more theoretical than I needed or would have liked. Rather than focusing on deriving equations I would have preferred more applied examples. Home works were extremely long. Final was very fair.

This course, and its companion half-credit course, are extremely poorly designed. Conceptually, the class was not particularly difficult. But the work to learning ratio was extraordinarily high, and I'm not sure that I have the tools to actually apply what I learned in real-world settings. In a broader picture, I'm not sure why YSPH has these two courses or what they are trying to get out of them. It's a fast-paced cram session that gives a very basic conceptual understanding, but not much more. I know students had similar criticisms last year, and nothing really changed, which was frustrating.Pros:1) The slides are well written and present information well.2) Maria and the TA were nice.Cons:1) The lecture literally involved just reading the slides.2) The problem sets were absurdly long -- I think most of mine were>25 typed pages. They are also extremely repetitive. If I can do one log likelihood test by hand, I can do 5 of them. I spent an absurd amount of time working on them but didn't learn much.3) I feel now that I can do the tests we learned 1) by hand or 2) in SAS. But I don't want to do them by hand, and have no idea where to start in any other language or application.4) An immense amount of information (~150 slides/week) were crammed into a very small space, leaving little time for understanding or digesting it, and not really allowing me to apply things outside of rather rigid conceptual frameworks. I could answer problem set questions from slides but I'm not sure I really could do more.5) Assignments were due on the same day of exams or right beforehand, meaning that we received no feedback and were likely to make the same mistakes on an exam that we did on the homework.6) There was no application of class information to real-world data.Suggestions:1) Condense these two classes into a single class, and don't try to do so much. Two half credit courses combined should be about the same as one class, but were actually more like 2-3 classes.2) Make lecture more useful, or vary class structure.3) Make assignments more reasonable in length and less repetitive.4) Emphasize real world applications more.5) Make code available for other languages, or discuss *how* to learn or think about the code rather than just providing samples.

This was a good course, teaching necessary skills for performing a survival analysis.It would have been nice to have more time. The half semester seemed really short and very rushed to complete all lectures and assignments.It would have been nice to have talked about time-varying (not time-dependent) covariates.

This course offers a thorough introduction to survival analysis. The course is well taught, and the lectures are clear and comprehensive. Homework assignments are long and sometimes tedious but do force you to review and apply key concepts.
This is a great course that will give you a strong foundation in survival analysis. The workload is significant as you have very long problem sets due weekly but you will gain a lot from it.
This course is more focus on application rather than theory.
I think this is an excellent course. I wish we would've had shorter homeworks (even if we had more). The prof and the TF were great though.
Very applied. Learned a lot.
A nice course.Useful and clear.
The assignments were very long, but covered appropriate material. The final did a good job of consolidating the course material as well.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  good
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Easy to follow her lecture
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Dr. Ciarleglio has the best slides and lectures in YSPH

Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Dr. Ciarleglio does an excellent job of teaching!Specifically, she is great at communicatin complicated information in a relatively simple way, which I truly value!Great job Dr. Ciarleglio, I wish you taught some of the other biostats course, esp. some of the lower level (fundamental courses).
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  The instructor is excellent, with very good communicating skills and course material she prepared.

Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Maria is an excellent professor. It is clear she is an expert in her field and she has the necessary teaching skills to transfer this knowledge through her lectures to her students.She understands that all of her students are not in the biostatistics department and teaches accordingly. I am so grateful to Maria as her two classes this semester have really made me understand statistics and how to apply statistics in a real-world way. I only wish all the statistics courses I took in my program could have been taught by Maria! Thank you Maria!
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  slides are very informative
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  She could engage the class a bit more.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Maria is one of the nicest people and is so good at statistics but it does not come across in this course.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  outstanding
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Explains everything very clearly. Professor was very responsive to questions (even emailing back at 10pm!)
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Maria is very nice, responds to emails and writes good slides, but lecture simply involves reading them and is not that helpful.

Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  The slides were fabulously detailed. They will be very useful for future reference.On the down side, the class wasn't very interactive, but that's just the nature of this type of material, I think.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Dr. Ciarleglio's presentations are clear and concise, and she is very responsive to students questions.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Dr. Ciarleglio is a fantastic teacher. She was very attentive to students and gave very thorough descriptions.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  The lecture notes are really well-organized, and help a lot.She is really nice. :)
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Dr. Ciarleglio is an excellent instructor. I wish I could take more classes with her. She is very clear and concise with explaining the material.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Very applied. Learned a lot.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Well-prepared and explicit lectures.A responsible instructor.
Instructor: Maria Michelle Ciarleglio  Maria is a wonderful instructor. Her course notes are incredibly clear.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Instructor: Kyaw Sint  good
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Nice
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Graded hw thoroughly
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Kyaw is an excellent TA, extremely patient and responsive to students questions and concerns.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Pretty good.

Instructor: Kyaw Sint  -Helpful in tutoring sessions / office hours.-Sometimes confused with course material, but responsive to emails and willing to help students learn.-He is a good addition to the course.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Joe is an excellent TA. He is very knowledgeable and he is able to explain the material in a straightforward manner. Thanks Joe for all your hard work this semester!
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  good
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  He is great!
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  great, I felt bad for him this was a lot of work for him
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  dedicated
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Very available for questions
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Joe was wonderful -- accessible, knowledgeable, and helpful. He responded promptly to emails, and was very nice. He was a great part of an otherwise frustrating course.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  very helpful!

Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Joe was great! He was willing to work with students on the homework, and did a good job of getting those long assignments back to us in a timely manner. Very nice and very helpful.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Always quick to give feedback. Wonderful
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Kyaw was responsive to students and had a solid grasp of the course material. He also graded and returned all assignments promptly.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Joe is great! He is very approachable and gives good feedback on the homeworks.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Very applied. Learned a lot.Very helpful
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  Helpful and responsible.
Instructor: Kyaw Sint  The TA provided good and prompt feedback.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: good
You could learn from it!
This is a very accelerated course with LONG hw assignments. You will learn a lot but work pretty hard
I would say the course requires a lot of time dedication, which is ultimately worth it in terms of gaining an understanding of the material.
This is a very useful and interesting area.
Excellent, I would highly recommend this course to those interested in learning about Survival Analysis.
Too much work! definitely not worth 0.5 credits
Don't take it. Its twice the work of a semester course and half the credit.
nice course

Short Answer:You might have to take the class, but if not, just get the slides from another student, and you'll get every benefit of it without as much of the hassle.Long Answer:This course, and its companion half-credit course, are extremely poorly designed. Conceptually, the class was not particularly difficult. But the work to learning ratio was extraordinarily high, and I'm not sure that I have the tools to actually apply what I learned in real-world settings. In a broader picture, I'm not sure why YSPH has these two courses or what they are trying to get out of them. It's a fast-paced cram session that gives a very basic conceptual understanding, but not much more. I know students had similar criticisms last year, and nothing really changed, which was frustrating.Pros:1) The slides are well written and present information well.2) Maria and the TA were nice.Cons:1) The lecture literally involved just reading the slides.2) The problem sets were absurdly long -- I think most of mine were>20-25 typed pages. They are also extremely repetitive. If I can do one log likelihood test by hand, I can do 5 of them. I spent an absurd amount of time working on them but didn't learn much.3) I feel now that I can do the tests we learned 1) by hand or 2) in SAS. But I don't want to do them by hand, and have no idea where to start in any other language or application.4) An immense amount of information (~150 slides/week) were crammed into a very small space, leaving little time for understanding or digesting it, and not really allowing me to apply things outside of rather rigid conceptual frameworks. I could answer problem set questions from slides but I'm not sure I really could do more.5) Assignments were due on the same day of exams or right beforehand, meaning that we received no feedback and were likely to make the same mistakes on an exam that we did on the homework.6) There was no application of class information to real-world data.Suggestions:1) Condense these two classes into a single class, and don't try to do so much. Two half credit courses combined should be about the same as one class, but were actually more like 2-3 classes.2) Make lecture more useful, or vary class structure.3) Make assignments more reasonable in length and less repetitive.4) Emphasize real world applications more.5) Make code available for other languages, or discuss *how* to learn or think about the code rather than just providing samples from which to work.

This is a class on learning how to do survival analysis by hand and with SAS. It is a lot of work, but it's a required class, so you have to take it. You formally learn things about survival analysis that you had sort of picked up in other classes. You also learn about parametric models, which you probably will rarely use.
I would recommend this course to anyone pursuing a career in epidemiology. It was one of the best statistics courses that I took at YSPH.
Great course! You will learn a lot about survival analysis which is a very important topic for doing medical research.
This course is more focus on application rather than theory.
Great class. Fast pace so don't fall behind. The homeworks are long but the professor is great at explaining the material.
Very applied. Learned a lot.
Useful.Recommend.

The course did a very good job of introducing survival analysis and it's uses and applications. Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it gave a very good overview of survival analysis.
